headline: Here We Go: High Stakes in Today's Ohio GOP Senate Primary
author: Guy Benson
sentences:
As we alluded to earlier, the Democrat in the race will be Congressman Tim Ryan, who's trying hard to run away from his party's toxic national brand:
Check out the latest Tim Ryan ad  running *against* his own party: https://t.co/WetiNtvhQi
 Josh Kraushaar (@HotlineJosh) May 3, 2022
The problem?

The snapshot of Sunday doesn't look anything like the snapshot of Friday.? https://t.co/WNy5QlZuRNhttps://t.co/QgILNJYpsB pic.twitter.com/ndyoCB5ESq
 John McCormack (@McCormackJohn) May 2, 2022
Per Trafalgar, 9 percent of likely Ohio GOP Senate primary voters are undecided.

Ryan was even one of the unanimous-minus-one House Democrats who voted to pass "Build Back Better," a $5 trillion inflation bomb that raises taxes on millions of middle-class households while carving out a generous tax break for blue state millionaires.

A solid majority of those undecided voters are backing Mike DeWine in the gubernatorial primary.https://t.co/Q18jKgPgy3 pic.twitter.com/XYBJfKAN1A
 John McCormack (@McCormackJohn) May 2, 2022
If that's all true, maybe Matt Dolan can pull off a shocker.

Meanwhile, another candidate is said to be surging at the tail end of the race, and he's the least overtly Trumpy option on the ballot:
Saturday and Sunday, there was a big Dolan surge,? says Robert Cahaly, the pollster who runs Trafalgar.
All of which is to say that whomever emerges on the GOP side tonight in Buckeye country will certainly have a lot of material to use against the presumptive Democratic nominee in the race.

He's doing great pic.twitter.com/wkP3KetanL
 Acyn (@Acyn) May 1, 2022
He mashed up the names of JD Vance, the candidate he actually endorsed, and Josh Mandel, one of Vance's opponents.
Trump waded into the mire and picked his man, helping Vance shoot up from a somewhat-floundering third or fourth-place candidate to a narrow frontrunner.
But his voting record is what it is, the Democrats' self-created mess in DC is what it is, and the president's disapproval rating is what it is.
Beyond that, it's hard to authentically argue that you're a maverick who stands up to your own party when...you don't actually do that.
A Vance loss would be a blow to the former president's aura of dominance and invincibility on the Right, with others likely to follow.
The nominee will emerge battered and bruised, facing the challenge of a rested and well-funded "moderate" Democrat in the general.
Mandel's supporters are running ads attacking Vance for opposing Trump in 2016, a move that has reportedly infuriated Trumpworld.
He votes like Pelosi and hasn't bucked Biden  who is 19 points underwater in Ohio, according to a recent poll  a single time.
He's already had to "un-endorse" his anointed Senate pick in Alabama, due to an impending failure  and his feud with Gov.
At long last, primary day has arrived, so this extended bout of intra-party warfare will soon be put out of its misery.
"My party sucks, vote for me to go save their majority is definitely an angle," snarks a Republican operative.
Ryan has voted for the Biden/Harris agenda literally 100 percent of the time, per a FiveThirtyEight analysis.
Maybe more than "a bit," from cartoonish confrontations to ridiculous ads to ugly sniping to weird pandering.
That combination should be enough to keep the seat in Republican hands, but nothing can be taken for granted.
Let's face it, the GOP US Senate primary in the Buckeye State has been a bit of a bleep-show from the start.
Ohio has reddened in recent years, and this is shaping up to be a red-to-scarlet-hued election cycle.
Second, this is the first major 2022 test of Trump's continued influence within Republican politics.
Donald Trump carried the state by eight points in 2016, then repeated the feat four years later.
It's been a crowded primary for months, with no candidate clearly pulling away from the pack.
Trump is out on a limb for Dr. Oz in Pennsylvania, and for JD Vance in Ohio.
That almost sounds too bad to be true, but it is an accurate assessment.
Brian Kemp in Georgia may also end poorly, from Trump's perspective.
A Vance victory would allow Trump to tout his kingmaker status.
Two big reasons: First, this is a must-hold seat for the party.
He'll play the part of a blue collar midwestern pragmatist.

Or JD something-or-other:
Trump: We've endorsed Dr.Oz.
Why are the stakes in this primary fight so high?
He talks like a "moderate" and "independent."
Ryan will be shrewd and won't lack for funds.
Advantage: J. Dolan Mandel.
But Vance is the favorite.
More on him in a moment.
We've endorsed JP right?
JD Mandell.
